verses.text: Solomon, the son of David, established himself firmly over his kingdom, and the Lord his God was with him and made him exceedingly great.
verses.comment: The phrase 'established himself' refers to Solomon securing his rule after David's death.

verses.text: Solomon spoke to all Israel, to the commanders of thousands and hundreds, to the judges, and to every leader in all Israel, the heads of the ancestral houses.
verses.comment: The term 'heads of ancestral houses' means leaders of the families or clans of Israel.

verses.text: So Solomon and all the assembly with him went to the high place that was at Gibeon, for the tent of meeting of God, which Moses the servant of the Lord had made in the wilderness, was there.
verses.comment: 'High place' here refers to Gibeon, where the tabernacle was located before the temple was built.

verses.text: But the ark of God David had brought up from Kiriath-jearim to the place David had prepared for it, for he had pitched a tent for it in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The Ark was separate from the tabernacle at this time, highlighting two worship locations.

verses.text: Moreover, the bronze altar that Bezalel the son of Uri, son of Hur, had made, was there in front of the tabernacle of the Lord. Solomon and the assembly sought it out.
verses.comment: 'Sought it out' describes their purpose to worship at the altar designed by Bezalel.

verses.text: Solomon went up to the bronze altar before the Lord, which was at the tent of meeting, and offered a thousand burnt offerings on it.
verses.comment: 'A thousand burnt offerings' emphasizes Solomon's devotion.

verses.text: That night God appeared to Solomon and said to him, 'Ask for whatever you wish me to give you.'
verses.comment: The Lord initiates Solomon’s famous request for wisdom.

verses.text: Solomon said to God, 'You have shown great and steadfast love to my father David, and have made me king in his place.'
verses.comment: 'Steadfast love' (Hebrew: hesed) speaks to God’s covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: 'Now, O Lord God, let your promise to David my father be confirmed, for you have made me king over a people as numerous as the dust of the earth.'
verses.comment: Solomon repeats God’s promise to Abraham (Gen. 13:16) regarding Israel’s number.

verses.text: 'Give me now wisdom and knowledge, so that I may lead this people, for who can govern this great people of yours?'
verses.comment: Solomon doesn’t ask for wealth or power, but for wisdom.

verses.text: God replied to Solomon, 'Because your heart desired this, and you did not ask for riches, possessions, honor, or the life of those who hate you, nor even for a long life, but you have asked for wisdom and knowledge to govern my people over whom I have made you king—'
verses.comment: The list matches other Old Testament motifs of wisdom versus worldly gain.

verses.text: 'wisdom and knowledge are granted to you. I will also give you riches, possessions, and honor, such as no king before you has had and none after you will have in all your days.'
verses.comment: God gives Solomon both wisdom and all the things he didn’t ask for.

verses.text: So Solomon came from the high place at Gibeon, from before the tent of meeting, to Jerusalem. And he reigned over Israel.
verses.comment: Solomon’s journey marks the beginning of his active rule.

verses.text: Solomon gathered together chariots and horsemen; he had one thousand four hundred chariots and twelve thousand horsemen, whom he stationed in the chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: 'Chariot cities' refers to strategically located military bases.

verses.text: The king made silver and gold as common in Jerusalem as stones, and cedar as plentiful as the sycamores of the lowlands.
verses.comment: 'Lowlands' refers to the geological Shephelah, west of Jerusalem.

verses.text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and Kue; the king’s merchants purchased them from Kue for a price.
verses.comment: 'Kue' is the ancient region also called Cilicia, in southern Turkey.

verses.text: They imported a chariot from Egypt for six hundred pieces of silver and a horse for one hundred fifty. In the same way they exported them to all the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Aram.
verses.comment: 'Hittites' and 'Aram' refer to neighboring kingdoms to the north and northeast of Israel.
